Country Context 

2. 
Socioeconomic  development. Viet Nam has enjoyed rapid economic growth over the 
past  decade.  Gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  per  capita  increased  from  $489.9  in  2003  to 
$1,052.7 in 2008. The real economic growth rate accelerated from 7.3% to 8.5% between 2003 
and  2007  before  dropping  to  6.2%  in  2008.  This  progress  rests  on  fast  export  growth,  higher 
farm  incomes,  and  strong  domestic  demand.  Exports  are  growing  by  15%–20%  per  year  in 
value terms, and foreign direct investment inflows by 10% per year.  
 
3. 
As  a  consequence  of  the  recent  economic  growth,  the  sectoral  composition  of  the 
economy has also drastically changed. In 1999, the country was primarily agricultural, with 76% 
of the population living in the rural areas and agricultural production accounting for 26% of GDP 
(1998). By 2007, the share of agriculture, forestry, and fishery had declined to 14.2% of GDP. 
The  share  of  industry,  on  the  other  hand,  has  been  climbing  and  is  now  at  43.3%,  while  the 
share of services has risen to 42.5%. By 2010, it is estimated that the agricultural labor force will 
have dropped to 50% but the labor force in industry and construction will have increased to 24% 
and the service labor force to 26%. Such a shift will require an educated and skilled workforce to 
support an economy based on services and industry.  
 
There  is  a  growing  need  for  more  than  just  equitable  compulsory  education.  Parents,

5. 
Enhancing  the  quality  of  the  labor  force  is  a  critical  element  for  Viet  Nam  to  retain 
regional  competitiveness  and  sustained  economic  growth.  In  2006  Vietnam  had  a  work  force

professional skills and knowledge such as information and communication technology (ICT) and 
proficiency in foreign languages. The quality of schooling and the learning outcomes of students 
need to be equivalent with other countries for Viet Nam to remain internationally competitive.

Viet  Nam’s  high  rate  of  economic  growth  has  had  a  positive  impact  on  poverty  and

incidence  was  reduced from  more  than  58%  in  1993  to less  than  20%  in  2007.  Youth  literacy

targets  related  to  health  care  have  been  met.  These  significant  achievements  have  raised 
Viet Nam’s  human  development  index  to  a  high  level  relative  to  that  for  other  countries  in  the 
same income group.  
 
8. 
Persistent  development  inequalities  by  region,  ethnicity,  disability,  and  gender. 
Having  achieved  impressive  overall  economic  growth  rates,  there  has  been  a  shift  in  poverty 
incidence—from being widespread throughout the population it is now concentrated in specific 
groups  that  are  harder  to  reach.  Four  groups  are  particularly  vulnerable:  rural  poor,  ethnic 
minorities, people with disabilities, and women and girls. 
 
In 2006, 20.4% of rural households were poor, compared with 3.9% of urban households. 
9. 
There  are  also  significant  differences  between  geographic  regions.  Poverty  is  highest  in  the 
North  West  region,  at  51.9%,  and  lowest  in  the  South  East,  at  6.1%.3 Ethnic  minorities,  in 
particular,  have  not  progressed  to  the  same  extent  as  other  groups.  In  2006,  52.3%  of  ethnic 
minority households were poor, compared with 10.3% of ethnic Kinh and Chinese households. 
Poverty  among  ethnic  minority  groups  is  closely  associated  with  low  or  limited  access  to 
opportunities  for  education  and  training,  often  resulting  in  low  agricultural  productivity  and 
exclusion from participation in local governance. 
 
10. 
As of March 2008, about 12.8 million persons have physical or mental disabilities in Viet 
Nam.4 While  the  Government  has  provided  financial  support  programs  to  the  disabled,  they 
remain  restricted  in  accessing  education  opportunities  leading  to  lack  of  life  skills  and  job 
opportunities. Provision of schooling at secondary level is particularly limited. Until 2000, there 
was only one lower secondary school in the country which was able to accept disabled children 
and  provide  integrated  education.  In  the  school  year  (SY)  2007/2008,  Viet  Nam  had  99,941 
disabled  students  receiving  schooling;  80,187  students  at  primary  schools,  but  only  17,329  at 
lower secondary school (LSS) and 2,425 at upper secondary school (USS).  
 
11.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Education Sector Performance Indicators  

12. 
Key investment option for development. Viet Nam considers education to be strongly 
linked  to  economic  growth  and  gives  it  priority  in  investments  for  the  socioeconomic 
development of the country. The central goal of education is rapid human resource development 
to  meet  labor  needs  in  a  highly  competitive  market  economy  while  ensuring  a  high  level  of 
equity. Viet Nam’s educated and low-cost workforce is an advantage, although this constitutes 
only 27% of the national labor force, compared with 50% in some other developing countries in 
the  region.6 The  Government  plans  to  increase  this  proportion  to  40%  by  2010,  and  60%  by 
2020.  However,  achieving  these  goals  will  depend  on  whether  education  in  Viet  Nam  can 
produce a workforce with the creative and analytical skills needed to compete in an increasingly 
industrial and knowledge-based economy.  
 
13. 
Education sector performance. Sustained efforts by the Government and development 
partners have resulted in relatively solid performance in education. In SY 2007–2008, the gross 
enrollment  rate  reached  95.2%  for  primary  education,  92%  for  LSE,  and  56.7%  for  USE. 
Participation rate in higher education was 13% in 2008. Having achieved near-universal primary 
education, as indicated in SEDP 2006–2010, the Government has made it the principal goal of 
the education sector to achieve universal LSE by 2015 and improve the education system and 
content  by  2015.  Overall,  the  Government  has  gradually  shifted  the  focus  of  public  services 
from  equitable  provision  to  better  quality  of  services.  However,  a  remaining  critical  need  is 
delivering  education  services  to  the  hardest-to-reach  groups  in  parallel  with  improving  the 
quality  and  effectiveness  of  secondary  education.  The  education  sector  is  analyzed  in 
Appendix 2. 
 
14. 
Education finance. Public education expenditure is increasing at a steady rate, favoring 
disadvantaged  areas.  The  current  sector  and  subsector  policy  frameworks  emphasize  these 
trends.  In  SY2006/07,  education  accounted  for  19.8%  of  total  public  expenditure  and  5.1%  of 
GDP. In subsector share of education expenditure, there were clear shifts in priorities between 
2001  and  2008  (i) from  technical  training  (24.1%  to  18.9%)  to  general  education  (75.8%  to 
81.0%);  (ii) from  primary  education  (32.7%  to  29.2%)  to  secondary  education  (LSE  and  USE) 
(30.4% to 40.59%); and (iii) from relatively wealthy regions to remote, ethnic minority regions, in 
particular, the Northern Mountainous, Central Highlands, and the Mekong River Delta regions.7

b. 

Quality and Relevance 

24. 
No  professional  certification  of  teachers.  While  more  than  80%  of  the  present  crop  of 
secondary  teachers  have  the  required  academic  qualifications  and  adequate  subject  knowledge, 
some lack practical teaching skills to motivate students to learn. Current teacher standards center 
on academic qualifications and not actual teaching skills. Besides, there is no professional teacher 
certification. While teachers are required to participate in some in-service teacher training programs, 
once they graduate from a teacher training college (TTC) or a teacher training university (TTU), their 
professional status as teachers is secured.  
 
25. 
Teachers need to upgrade their qualifications—both in subject knowledge and teaching 
skills—in order to meet the standards required for registration. There is also a pressing need for 
them to be brought up-to-date with the latest education technology. Qualified teachers seeking 
re-entry  into  the  teaching  workforce  need  a  similar  range  of  in-service  courses.  The 
development of teacher standards will provide a clearer indication of the teaching skills, subject 
knowledge and attributes needed by teachers and will be incorporated into both pre-service and 
in- service programs. 
 
26. 
Poor assessment of learning outcomes. The concept of “learning outcomes” is new to 
Viet Nam. Learning outcomes are often seen as amounts of memorized knowledge rather than 
the acquired ability to think analytically, solve problems, and take a suitable attitude to learning 
required  to  compete  successfully  in  the  international  labor  market.  MOET  has  established  an 
assessment  monitoring  and  management  system  for  all  levels  of  education  including  the 
provincial departments of education and training (DOETs) and the district bureaus of education 
and training. 
 
27. 
A  valid  and  reliable  system  and  standard  for  students’  performance  and  attainments  is 
still  being  developed,  although  MOET  has  been  monitoring  student  performance  through

national  achievement  monitoring  (NAM)  program  for  primary  education,  but  so  far  there  has 
been no such initiative for secondary education.  
 
28. 
To improve the assessment of learning outcomes, MOET plans to participate by 2012 in 
the Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) of the Organisation for Economic 
Co-operation  and  Development  (OECD).  PISA  compares  the  performance  of  15  year-old 
students  near  the  end  of  basic  education  across  different  countries  using  internationally

adequacy  of  knowledge  and  skills  acquired  by  students  for  full  participation  in  society.  The 
domains  of  reading,  mathematical  and  scientific  literacy,  problem-solving  skills,  and  analytical 
skills are covered.

the  cost  of  education;  youth  in  special  need  of  protection;  youth  affected  by  HIV/AIDS;  and 
youth in the juvenile justice system. The aim of the equivalency programs is to draw these youth

Limited  participation  of  disabled  children.  A  lack  of  social  awareness  regarding 
disability  issues,  combined  with  traditional  negative  stereotypes,  can  restrict  educational

excluded from access to education, particularly at the secondary level. The high direct costs of 
education  for  families  are  also  a  deterrent,  as  families  do  not  value  the  education  of  disabled 
children or spend much of their earnings caring for the disabled child.

participation rate for disabled children will be a major task. Moreover, students must be able to 
participate in the full curriculum and realize their intellectual potential. As special schools cost a 
great  deal  to  build  and  operate,  one  alternative  would  be  to  start  by  equipping  classrooms  in 
one  LSS  in  each  province.  Students  could  be  integrated  into  mainstream  classes  for  some 
courses, and attend special classes for others.

ANALYSIS OF THE EDUCATION SECTOR  

1. 
Sector  overview.  Viet  Nam  has  experienced  significant  economic  success  over  recent 
years. This success has resulted from considerable effort being directed at developing a skilled 
and  knowledgeable  workforce  through  a  focus  on  improving  educational  opportunities  for  all. 
While this success is applauded, a closer analysis of the situation indicates that only 27% of the 
national  labor  force  meets  international  training  standards,  compared  with  50%  for  other 
developing  countries  in  the  region.  However,  the  Government  recognizes  that,  to  remain 
competitive, it must increase the educational levels of the workforce. It has therefore set for itself 
the target of improving the proportion of the workforce with the required formal skills to 40% by 
2010, and to 60% by 2020. 
 
This  need  to  build  capacity  through  a  greater  focus  on  policy  development,  as  well  as 
2. 
continued  support  for  targeted  programs,  stems  in  part  from  the  reality  that  Viet  Nam  is  rapidly 
advancing  toward  an  average  per  capita  income  of  $1,000,  which  it  is  expected  to  achieve  by 
2010. This will result in its being accorded middle-income country status and eventually lead to 
greater internal funding of educational programs. For the country to make a successful transition 
from  aid  dependence  to  increased  financial  self-reliance,  it  must  develop  greater  policy  and 
strategic  planning  capacity.  This  will  require  improved  internal  capacity  to  collect  and  analyze 
data as the basis for identifying future areas of need, and to use resources effectively to improve 
access to and the quality of capacity building programs.  
 
3. 
Policy  planning  and  finance  under  decentralization.  The  Ministry  of  Education  and 
Training  (MOET)  oversees  the  education  sector  and  is  responsible  for  setting  broad  policy 
directions  for  all  levels  of  education.  However,  management  responsibility  for  school  buildings, 
staffing,  and  distribution  of  financial  resources  has  been  progressively  decentralized,  with 
universities  being  directly  managed  by  MOET,  upper  secondary  education  schools  (USSs)  and 
professional  secondary  schools  being  managed  at  the  provincial  level  by  the  departments  of 
education and training, and lower secondary schools and primary schools being managed locally 
in the districts or communes by district bureaus of education and training. Service provision has 
become  increasingly  decentralized  through  the  removal  of  controls  from  the  center  and  the 
increase in revenue-raising powers at the local level.  
 
4. 
While  all  local  governments  must  adopt  national  policies,  there  are  considerable 
differences in educational outcomes between regions and provinces. Reducing gaps in regional 
educational performance outcomes is central to improving national performance and is one of the 
biggest challenges facing both developing and developed countries. All students, irrespective of 
their local circumstances, must have access to good-quality schooling. The central Government 
must  therefore  play  a  major  role  in  seeing  to  it  that  all  schools  meet  minimum  performance 
standards  by  implementing  national  policies  that  are  constantly  reviewed  and  amended  on  the 
basis  of  periodic  and  comprehensive  monitoring  and  assessment  of  sector  performance  and 
results.  Part  of  this  process  will  be  reviewing  funding  arrangements,  although  this  will  be  an 
activity over the longer term, when more valid and reliable national data become available. 
 
School  funding  is  a  complex  process,  with  revenue  provided  at  the  State,  province,  and 
5. 
local levels. Funds provided by the State are distributed according to a per-capita weighted index 
of disadvantage. This is supplemented at the local level through the application of fees that cover 
necessary teaching and learning expenses and school development. Through targeted programs, 
the  State  provides  fee  relief  and  scholarships  to  students  who  are  policy  beneficiaries,  such  as 
ethnic minorities, students who live in difficult circumstances, the poor, and excellent learners in 
both public and nonpublic schools at all levels of schooling.

Quality  assurance  of  secondary  schools. While secondary school provision continues 
6. 
to  expand,  many  rural  and  isolated  students  still  have  considerable  difficulty  gaining  access  to 
good-quality  secondary  education.  Many  poorer  communities  have  secondary  schools  whose 
facilities are not suited to the modern pedagogical approaches adopted by teachers. With limited 
facilities,  teachers  cannot  use  small-group  and  problem-solving  approaches  that  are  central  to 
improving learning outcomes.  
 
Several standards have been developed to assist in the establishment of quality schools. 
7. 
International standards provide broad guidelines for lower secondary schools (LSSs) and USSs 
and assist in the development of national standards to guarantee access to facilities that facilitate 
good-quality  learning  for  all  students.  National  standards  are  now  being  developed,  but  these 
must  undergo  quality  assurance  to  make  certain  that  the  standards  equate  with  current 
international  standards.  As  part  of  this  process,  fundamental  school  quality  levels  are  being 
developed  for  LSSs;  similar  standards  must  also  be  developed  for  USSs,  as  part  of  future 
investment  projects.  While  high  national  standards  are  a  central  part of  a  strong national  policy 
framework, they must apply nationwide and all schools must meet these standards irrespective of 
location or local circumstances. 
 
8. 
Private provision of schooling. The majority of formal education and training is publicly 
provided  through  state-run  schools,  colleges,  universities,  and  training  centers.  There  are, 
however,  a  number  of  nonpublic  institutions  operating  at  each  level.  The  Government  has 
established a policy of encouraging the development of nonpublic or private schools, although the 
education  law  states  that  private,  people-funded,  and  semipublic  schools  all  belong  to  and 
contribute to the national education system. Nonpublic schools therefore benefit from incentives 
related to facilities, land, taxes, fees, credit, insurance, and commendation and reward systems. 
The  same  expectations  and  laws  apply  to  both  nonpublic  and  public  schools  in  the 
implementation  of  the  objectives,  contents,  curriculum,  textbooks,  teaching  methods,  and 
regulations relating to enrollment, teaching and learning, examinations, completion requirements, 
diploma certification, and other matters. The nonpublic school system has been established at all 
education levels, from early childhood care to higher education. 
  
However, what is apparent is the lack of quality control across all schools and of national 
9. 
standards for the quality of facilities and for the competencies and professional skills required for 
effective teaching, as well as an improved curriculum. Current policies will have to  be reviewed 
and new strategic plans developed for a coordinated national approach to improvement.  
 
10.  While the need to develop national standards has been mentioned, these standards must 
apply  to  all  schools.  Current  performance  data  highlight  considerable  national  variation  in  the 
quality of schools and in student achievement. To improve national consistency and reliability, an 
independent,  specialized  agency  must  be  established  to  accredit  schools,  so  that  all  students, 
irrespective  of  their  local  circumstances,  have  access  to  good  schools  and  programs.  This 
agency  will  also  assist  in  strategic  decision making,  as  areas  of  need  are  identified  through 
independent,  objective  analysis  of  performance,  and  provide  the  Government  with  relevant  and 
accurate data for the effective deployment of resources. 
 
11. 
Quality  assurance  of  secondary  teachers.  There  is  considerable  evidence  that  the 
quality  of  teaching  is  central  to  improving  student  learning  outcomes,  as  good  teachers  are 
knowledgeable and able to use a range of pedagogical approaches to improve student learning 
outcomes.  Recent  research  on  what  teachers  should  know  and  should  be  able  to  do  has  been 
used to develop a range of teacher standards. This development has  been critical to improving 
teacher  performance,  as  it  has  enabled  analytical  and  objective  analysis  of  performance.  Many

systems use teacher standards to make certain that all teachers have the skills, knowledge, and 
attributes  to  teach  well.  These  standards  inform  training  programs  and  focus  professional 
development programs on improving teacher effectiveness.  
 
12. 
They  are  also  used  as  the  basis  for  initial  selection  and  promotion,  as  there  is  a  high 
correlation between standards and student learning outcomes. While student learning outcomes 
are  critical  to  evaluating  teacher  effectiveness,  they  should  be  used  within  a  broader  teacher 
standards framework, as not all students come from backgrounds that assist learning. Processes 
are  being  developed  to  measure  the  “value-added”  component  of  teacher  effectiveness,  where 
student  background  factors  are  acknowledged  and  measured,  enabling  judgments  to  be  made 
about what an individual teacher adds to a student’s learning irrespective of background factors. 
For teacher standards to be effectively used, support must be given for their use as the basis for 
initial training, for the upgrading of qualifications and skills, and for promotion. 
 
13. 
Human  resource  management  of  teachers.  Effectively managing teachers is critical to 
improving  student  learning  nationwide.  To  start  with,  a  teacher  workforce  plan  that  identifies 
future teacher needs must be developed on the basis of projected enrollment and teacher attrition. 
This  analysis  must  be  refined  to  identify  locations  and  specialist  subject  teachers  where  future 
shortages  are  likely.  Teacher  training  can  thus  be  planned  so  that  sufficient,  but  not  excessive, 
numbers of teachers are trained to meet projected needs. Incentives may have to be provided to 
meet expected vacancies in hard-to-staff locations.  
 
14. 
The  initial  process  of  selecting  potential  teachers  must  also  be  better  planned  to  better 
ensure that those who enter teacher training have the required attributes and abilities to develop 
into successful teachers. Countries like Singapore and Finland use rigorous selection based on 
teacher  standards  to  select  candidates  for  teacher  training.  National  teacher  graduation 
standards also make certain that all teacher-training graduates meet national standards, and that 
students,  irrespective  of  location,  are  taught  by  teachers  who  meet  the  national  standards. 
Graduates  also  require  support  in  their  first  years  of  teaching,  and  the  support  must  be  of  high 
quality.  Teacher  standards  for  experienced  and  highly  effective  teachers  allow  teacher 
effectiveness, and no longer years of service, to be used as the basis for promotion.  
 
Good  teachers  are  critical  to  improving  student-learning  outcomes,  but  so  are  highly 
15. 
competent  school  principals.  Many  educational  systems,  recognizing  the  centrality  of  school 
leadership, have established leadership colleges and developed standards for school leaders and 
principals.  Many  require  prospective  principals  to  demonstrate  that  they  meet  leadership 
standards before they can be considered for appointment. 
 
16.  Many of the aspects associated with effective human resource management of teachers 
are  currently  under  development,  but  much  more  is  needed  before  a  national  and  consistent 
approach  to  the  overall  management  of  teachers  is  achieved.  Such  an  approach  is  central  to 
improving teacher effectiveness and improving student learning outcomes. 
 
17. 
Learning  assessment  system.  National  tests  that  are  more  valid,  more  reliable,  and 
fairer are proposed. Viet Nam’s participation in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and 
Development  (OECD)  Programme  for  International  Student  Assessment  (PISA)  in  2012  would 
enable educational policy planners to analyze performance between provinces and districts, and 
to compare national performance against international norms. Better strategic decisions would be 
made, equalizing opportunities as well as highlighting national areas for further development. It is 
anticipated that participation in PISA will enable 15-year old students to apply the knowledge and 
skills  they  have  acquired  to  solve  problems,  and  teachers  to  gain  an  increased  focus  on 
more-effective educational practices instead of rote learning.

18.  While PISA will provide an invaluable assessment of national performance, it uses only a 
small sample of students to measure national performance. Current assessment practices must 
be improved at all levels of schooling. These assessment practices must be both formative and 
summative. Formative assessment allows teachers to monitor student learning progressively and 
use  the  information  gained  to  improve  teaching  practice.  As  teachers  become  more  competent 
and professional, they can meet identified learning needs by adopting a range of approaches to 
teaching.  This  is  especially  important  in  meeting  the  individual  and  group  needs  of  particular 
students  and  addressing  concerns  over  different  learning  styles  often  associated  with  ethnicity 
and gender. A range of teacher support material will have to be developed so that teachers have 
access to a variety of materials that will meet the particular needs of various students. Summative 
assessment, which has traditionally measured what has been learned after a study unit or subject 
is  completed,  is  still  important  but  new  and  more  innovative  assessment  practices  should  be 
further explored to ensure that the assessment covers both knowledge and the student’s ability to 
use the knowledge and skills acquired. 
 
At  the  national  level  there  is  the  opportunity  to  develop  assessment  materials  that 
19. 
demonstrate  to  teachers  how  they  can  assess  a  student’s  ability  to  apply  knowledge  to  solve 
problems. Such sample assessment materials encourage teachers to see that the application of 
knowledge and skills is central to achieving high-quality learning outcomes that are relevant in the 
workplace  and  central  to  economic  and  social  progress.  This  focus  on  analytical  skills  and 
problem solving must be central to the development of teacher standards and the effective use of 
different pedagogies and assessment practices. 
 
Curriculum and textbook upgrading. Processes must be put in place for the systematic 
20. 
review  of  the  curriculum  to  ensure  that  it  supports  the  achievement  of  national  goals,  including 
improved competence in English. This is critically important, as the Government has made clear 
its  reliance  on  the  ability  of  the  educational  system  to  produce  high-quality  graduates  who  can 
drive future economic growth, as well as to increase social harmony and reduce the gap between 
the advantaged and the disadvantaged.  
 
21. 
The  relevance  and  quality  of  the  curriculum  and  the  assessment  practices  used  to 
measure  success  must  be  ensured.  A  broad  range  of  people,  including  teachers,  principals, 
employers,  and  international  experts,  must  be  involved  in  this  process.  Approaches  to  effective 
teaching  should  be  constantly  reviewed,  together  with  the  curriculum  and  the  support  materials 
provided to teachers. A number of nations are creating teacher “idea banks,” where teachers post 
effective  approaches  to  teaching  on  a  dedicated  website.  Because  these  idea  banks  undergo 
quality assurance, what is available is typically of high quality. Such practices make possible the 
strategic  review  of  the  curriculum  and  the  introduction  of  systematic  improvements  to  meet 
changing needs and put new technologies to the best use to improve student learning. 
 
22. 
As teachers increase their professionalism, they will move from using a single prescribed 
text  to  using  a  variety  of  materials  that  better  enable  them  to  achieve  the  learning  outcomes 
sought. This will require a move from a single prescribed text to recommending several texts that 
can  be  used  depending  on  the  preference  of  the  teacher  and  the  learning  style  of  the  student. 
This practice also helps students prepare better for university and further study, where they will 
be required to source information and learning from various sources, including the internet. 
 
Continuing  education. While considerable effort has been targeted to ethnic minorities, 
23. 
there are ongoing concerns that the Government’s policies that place a high priority on supporting 
ethnic-minority  students  have  not  achieved  the  outcomes  sought.  New  policies  and  support 
programs must be explored and pilot studies undertaken to identify how current performance and

ensure  that  more  effective  policies  and  practices  are  adopted  nationally  in  this  key  area  of 
disadvantage.  The  pilot-testing  of  new  approaches  will  better  ensure  that  targeted  support 
achieves the goal of improving secondary educational outcomes for the poor. Approaches such 
as conditional cash transfers, which tie support to the successful participation and involvement of

Education  for  children  with  special  needs.  The  Government  has  decreed  that  all 
24. 
students,  irrespective  of  background  circumstances,  should  receive  a  good  education.  This 
especially applies to students with disabilities, as there is a need to ensure that their abilities and 
aspirations  are  recognized  and  addressed.  As  students  with  disabilities  live  within  the  broader 
community there are increasing trends to educate these students as part of mainstream schooling. 
Students such as those with physical disabilities and those with limited sight or hearing are being 
increasingly  integrated  into  mainstream  schools.  They  are  thus  provided  with  access  to  the  full 
range  of  programs  available  to  other  students,  who  go  through  the  experience  of  living  and 
learning  with  these  disabled  students.  This  process  provides  greater  opportunities  to  disabled 
students and develops a greater appreciation of their skills and abilities in the rest of the students. 
Such  an  inclusive  approach  to  disability  better  ensures  that  all  students  develop  increased 
understanding of diversity and improved social harmony. 
 
25. 
For such an approach to succeed, specialist teachers must be trained to support disabled 
students through direct teaching and other forms of support, possibly involving specialist classes 
for part of the day as well as support for particular students within mainstream classes.  
 
26. 
Transition  to  postsecondary  education.  As  a  country  committed  to  having  a 
knowledgeable and effective workforce operating within a harmonious society, Viet Nam aspires 
to have its people involve themselves in lifelong learning. This starts with school graduates either 
continuing with  their  education  in tertiary  institutes  or,  if  moving  directly  to  work,  participating in 
work-based learning programs. For this to be effective, plans must be developed to facilitate the 
transition from school to further study or work. In this process, students are counseled in school in 
selecting  subjects  that  provide  a  pathway  to  further  study  or  work  that  meets  their  aspirations, 
interests,  and  abilities.  Work  experience  programs  may  be  developed  so  that  school  students 
work for a short time within an industry or profession to gain a better understanding of post-school 
options.  Employers  and  tertiary  institutes  must  take  increased  interest  in  school  programs  to 
ensure continuity and relevance of learning. Final school assessment practices must also reflect 
the  various  post-school  pathways  open  to  students.  Some  assessment  programs  will  require 
students to demonstrate academic excellence; others will be based on particular competencies. 
Whichever approach is deemed to be more suitable, all will need to ensure that they encourage 
learning to be seen as dynamic and personally fulfilling.

IMPLEMENTATION PLAN FOR THE CONDITIONAL CASH TRANSFER PILOT PROGRAM1 

While  Viet  Nam’s  high  economic  growth  in  the  past  decade  has  significantly  reduced 
1. 
poverty, about 16% of the population remains poor. Poverty is associated with poor access to 
education  and  illiteracy,  and  lack  of  basic  education  excludes  the  uneducated  from  economic 
opportunities and limits access to higher incomes.  
 
2. 
Viet Nam has made great progress in improving the quality of education at the primary 
and  secondary  levels,  and  national  statistics  show  little  difference  in  school  achievement 
between boys and girls. However, national statistics do not reflect the differences, including the 
gender  gap,  between  ethnic  groups  and  regions,  especially  between  ethnic-minority  girls  and 
boys in poor districts. While the national net enrollment rate for lower secondary school (LSS) is 
80%, in the Northwest provinces, where 39% of the people remain poor, the net enrollment rate 
is only 60%, and only 73% of the women are literate, compared with 90% of the men.  
 
3. 
The cost of education is a key reason cited for the lower schooling outcomes of the poor 
and  ethnic  minorities.  In  recent  years,  the  cost  of  schooling  has  increased  by  47%,  adversely 
affecting  the  access  of  the  poor  and  girls  to  education.  Average  expenditure  on  education  in 
school year 2005–2006 increased in comparison with 2003–20042 and, on average, households 
paid  D1.211  million  per  person.  School  fees,  expenditure  for  extra  classes,  and  other 
educational expenditure accounted for large proportions of education expenditure of household 
members.  Costs  also  include  school  supplies,  clothes,  and  adequate  food.  For  the  poorest 
quintile, education expenditure represents 6%–7% of total household expenditure. A survey of 
Program 135  communes  gave  the  following  main  reasons  for  dropping  out  of  school  or  not 
attending  school  (i) cost  of  education  (62%),  (ii) unwillingness  to  attend  school  (59%),  and 
(iii) the need to work (27%) (footnote 2). 
 
4. 
Conditional  cash  transfers  (CCTs)  have  generated  significant  attention  in  addressing 
education attendance and outcomes by compensating the parents for the cost of sending their 
children to school. As the findings from the 2006 Viet Nam Household Living Standard Survey 
(VHLSS)  suggest  that  the  opportunity  costs  of  sending  children  to  school  are  high,  financial 
incentives  such  as  CCTs  could  be  effective  in  addressing  education  access  and  outcomes. 
However,  in  addition  to  demand-side  issues  of  school  enrollment  and  attendance  related  to 
financial barriers, the quality of schools and distance to them must be addressed.  
 
5. 
Pilot  conditional  cash  transfer  program  in  communities.  The  proposed  pilot 
community CCT program for Viet Nam’s lower secondary students is aimed at reducing extreme 
poverty  and  hunger  among  families,  and  improving  the  human  capital  of  children  of  poor 
households.  The  pilot  program  will  also  address  supply  gaps  in  the  subsector  through 
community participation and school block grants. The Ministry of Education and Training (MOET) 
has  gained  significant  experience  in  implementing  targeted  programs  for  the  poor  and  is  in  a 
position to implement the proposed community CCT program. The proposed program will also 
take advantage of the high social capital in rural areas that has proven to be a great source of 
assistance, enabling communities to take collective action to tackle common demand-side and 
supply-side problems to improve access to services.

Households grants. The household grant will provide cash (about $120 per student per 
year for 4 years) to extreme poor families with children 11–14 years of age on the condition that 
the children enroll in LSSs and attend at least 85% of classes. The cash transfers will be made

verification that the families have met the conditions. A slightly higher allocation will be given if a

8.

required attendance of over 85% of school classes. If the mother is not present in the household, 
the payment will be made to the household head. The grant will be given for all LSS students in 
the household who fulfill the conditions regardless of the LSS year attended, excluding students 
currently  receiving  scholarships.  However,  if  a  household  has  three  students  in  LSS  and  only 
one is on scholarship, the two remaining students will be eligible for the CCT program.

Program Flow and Implementation 

19. 
Project  cycle.  The  community  CCT  will  follow  a  cycle  consisting  of  five  main  stages: 
(i) information dissemination, (ii) school board planning and selection, (iii) distribution of grants, 
(iv) verification of compliance with conditions, and (v) performance monitoring and evaluation.  
 
20. 
The  information  dissemination  stage  will  provide  an  orientation  on  the  project 
background to provincial, district, and commune administrators, school administrators, parents’ 
associations, and representatives of the Viet Nam Women’s Union and ethnic minorities in the 
localities where the program will be implemented. The rationale, objectives, and process flow of 
the program will be discussed with the different groups, and their responsibilities in the program 
clarified.  This  stage  will  culminate  in  the  creation  of  a  school  board  composed  of  the  different 
groups involved in the program.

21. 
School boards will then take the lead in assessing the qualifications of households and 
LSSs to become beneficiaries of the program. They will also plan activities for the target schools 
to  be  financed  from  the  school  block  grants.  Schools  boards  will  also  approve  subsequent 
releases of funds to households and school administrators. 
 
22. 
The  grants  will  be  distributed  in  tranches.  For households,  an  initial  1-month  allocation 
will  be  given  upon  the  signing  of  their  agreement  with  the  program  and  its  conditions. 
Subsequent releases will be based on compliance with the condition of enrollment and school 
attendance.  Schools  will  receive  grants  based  on  the  plans  submitted  and  approved  by  the 
DOET. Subsequent releases will depend on the progress of funded activities. 
 
Verification of compliance will occur between the first and subsequent fund releases. This 
23. 
will be initiated by teachers (for school attendance) and the school administrators (for school block 
grant activities). Compliance will be reviewed by the school boards and appropriate action will be 
decided by them to assist households and schools in case of difficulties in meeting conditions. 
 
24.  Monitoring  and  evaluation.  In  collaboration  with  the  Government  Statistics  Office,  an 
impact  evaluation  of  the  program  will  be  developed  to  measure  program  benefits.  Community 
CCT  areas  and  households  will  be compared  with  similar  but  nonparticipating  communes  and 
families. Before the program starts, a baseline survey measuring consumption, education, and 
other  socioeconomic  variables  will  be  conducted  for  a  random  sample  of  beneficiary  and 
non-beneficiary  families  and  LSSs.  This  will  determine  the  baseline  indicators  against  which 
progress  will  be  measured.  The  program  will  also  have  a  monitoring  component  to  track 
progress in implementation, and compliance with conditions.  
 
25. 
Grievance  and  complaints  resolution.  Households  and  communities  can  direct  their 
questions or complaints to the PMU or directly to the school board, to representatives of parents 
and  ethnic  minority  groups,  or  school  administrators.  The  school  board  will  function  as  a 
complaints  handling  unit.  Noncompliance  with  the  conditions  of  the  program  and  the  of 
resources for activities other than those approved will be penalized.  
 
Penalties will take the form of warning, temporary suspension, or permanent suspension 
26. 
from the benefits of the program. A warning will be issued to mothers or other household heads 
and schools that do not meet commitments after one payment cycle. Temporary suspension will 
be imposed on mothers or other household heads and schools that fail to meet the conditions 
for two consecutive payment cycles. Mothers and schools may however request readmission to 
the  program.  In  all  cases,  the  school  board  will  investigate  the  cause  of  noncompliance  and 
develop  an  action  plan  with  the  mother  and  school  administrator  to  assist  the  household  or 
school in complying with conditions. Permanent suspension will be imposed on households and 
schools that fail to meet conditions after 1 year. No readmission will be allowed in this case.

A. Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The  Government  of  Viet  Nam  recognizes  secondary  education  as  one  of  the  principal  mechanisms  for 
achieving  economic  growth,  poverty  reduction  and  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs).  The 
Secondary  Education  Sector  Development  Program  (SESDP)  supports  Viet  Nam’s  5-year  Socio-Economic 
Development Plan (SEDP) 2006–2010, which targets universal secondary education as a key priority. Special 
emphasis is placed on reaching ethnic minorities in remote areas for equitable and inclusive development. Key 
targets include (i) universal upper secondary education in all provinces, (ii) a reduction in poverty to 10%–11% 
of households, (iii) an increase to 90% in the net enrollment rate among children of lower secondary school 
age,  and  (iv)  an  increase  to  more  than  50%  in  the  net  enrollment  rate  among  children  of  upper  secondary 
school  age.  The  Secondary  Education  Sector  Master  Plan  2006–2010  identifies  three  core  issues:  (i) 
persistent  inequality  of  access  to  schooling,  (ii)  weak  system  and  strategies  for  improving  the  quality  of 
teaching and learning, and (iii) lack of an accountability framework for effective delivery.  
 
The country partnership strategy (CPS) for Viet Nam 2007–2010a of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) is 
directly  linked  to  supporting  the  SEDP’s  targeted  outcomes,  including  expanded  access  to  good-quality 
services, especially for ethnic minorities. The Program responds to both Government and ADB priorities by 
supporting fundamental legal and policy reforms related to improving secondary education in Viet Nam.  
 
B. 
Development Goals (TI-M) 
1.    Key Issues  

Poverty Analysis         Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention–non-income Millennium 

Viet Nam continues to make impressive progress in poverty reduction and socioeconomic development and 
the  national  poverty  rate  has  fallen  from  58.1%  in  1993  to  less  than  20%  in  2007.  Viet  Nam  has  already 
achieved the poverty target under the MDGs and is on track to achieve most of the MDG targets by 2015. 
Most  human  development  indicators  have  risen  steadily  and  are  now  comparable  with  those  of 
middle-income countries.  

Despite  the steady  progress reflected  in  national statistics,  wide  variations  and  inequities persist.  In  2006, 
20.4%  of  rural  households  were  poor,  compared  with  3.9%  of  urban  households,  and  52.3%  of  ethnic 
minorities were poor compared with 10.3% of ethnic Kinh and Chinese households. In 2006, close to 9% of 
rural  households  and  29%  of  ethnic  minority  households  also  suffered  hunger  during  some  periods  of  the 
year.  While  the  urban  poverty  rate  is  relatively  low,  it  also  appears  to  have  stagnated  or  even  increased, 
suggesting that economic growth alone will not reduce poverty in urban centers, and that inflation and other 
factors may be pushing more people below the poverty line. Households whose consumption is just over the 
poverty  line  are  vulnerable  to  external  shocks  and  remain  at  risk  of  falling  back  below  the  poverty  line, 
particularly in the current global financial environment.  

 

 

 

Poverty,  particularly  among  minority  groups,  is  closely  associated  with  low  or  limited  access  to  education. 
The main barriers to access are lack of infrastructure, physical inaccessibility, language and cultural barriers, 
lack of good-quality teachers, curricula that are not suited to local needs or languages, and high costs. The 
opportunity  costs  for  many  ethnic  minority  and  poor  families  of  sending  their children  to secondary  school 
versus  working  for  the  family  are  high.  Fee  exemption  policies  are  often  insufficient  to  cover  all 
education-related costs associated with attending secondary education and many families cannot afford to 
send  their  children  to  school  because  of  these  financial  constraints.  The  financial  obligations  are  only 
exacerbated  in  rural  and  remote  regions  of  the  country,  and  this  places  a  large  burden  on  already 
cash-strapped families. Financial constraints were among the top two reasons students from 42 provinces in 
2004 were unable to attend school.

2. Design Features 
 
The  Program  supports  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  and social  development  goals  by  supporting a 
more  equitable  distribution  of  high-quality  secondary  education.  It  will  provide  direct  benefits  to 
ethnic-minority  and  poor  students  by  increasing  access  to  and  affordability  of  lower  secondary  education 
(LSE). The pilot conditional cash transfer (CCT) will address demand-side constraints and alleviate the direct 
and indirect costs of education. It will improve the human capital of children of poor households and reduce 
intergenerational poverty in the future. The pilot program will also address supply gaps in the sector through 
community participation and school block grants, and community awareness-raising activities will focus on 
demonstrating the benefits of school participation. The pilot program is expected to have significant impact 
in reducing poverty for poor households, increasing school attendance, increasing transition rates from lower 
secondary school (LSS) to upper secondary school (USS), increasing the years of education completed by 
poor children, and reducing child labor.  
         
C. Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
 
The  policy  reforms  included  in  the  Program  are  expected  to  positive  impact,  especially  for  the  poor  and 
those living in remote areas.  
 

The new national standards for secondary schools will ensure that all schools have appropriate 
levels of school buildings and facilities and provision of adequate numbers of quality instructional 
materials. This is especially important in rural areas, where costs of education are often higher 
but incomes lower. The updated school standards will ensure that no matter where a school is 
built, it will meet national standards for effective teaching and learning.  
 
The human resource management framework will ensure that teacher placements are matched 
to  need  and  that  teachers,  particularly  those  who  live  and  work  in  difficult  conditions,  are 
rewarded for efforts and effectiveness.  
 
The Decision on Regulations and Roles for Continuing Education Centers redefines the function 
of and quality standards for continuing education and will promote greater equity of opportunities 
for disadvantaged youth. Continuing education has been a key alternative learning opportunity 
for disadvantaged youth who cannot access or remain in the regular LSSs because of poverty, 
long distance to school, or the need to engage in seasonal labor. However, poor quality of the 
programs  and  limited  facilities,  which  cannot  absorb  increasing  demand,  have  been  a  key 
obstacle to the universalization of LSE. 
 
The  Decision  on  an  “inclusive  approach”  to  special  education  will  ensure  that  more  disabled 
students are able to gain access to mainstream schools. 
 
CCTs will promote poverty reduction and enhanced access to education for poor families.  

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Poverty  rates  and  education  indicators  lag  substantially  behind  in  the  Northwest  and  Central  Highlands 
regions,  in  rural  areas,  and  among  the  most  marginalized  ethnic  groups.  Viet  Nam  has  54  officially 
recognized ethnic groups, with the ethnic Kinh composing over 86%. Except for the ethnic Chinese, Khmer, 
and Cham, ethnic minorities reside mainly in remote, mountainous, and other disadvantaged areas. While 
they represent less than 15% of the population, these minorities accounted for 44% of the poor and 59% of 
the hungry in 2006. Viet Nam’s ethnic minorities are extremely heterogeneous, and their relative positions 
appear  to  be  shifting  significantly.  While  the  ethnic  Chinese,  Khmer,  and  Cham  have  improved  theire 
position  relative  to  the  Kinh  majority,  the  relative  positions  of  several  Northern  and  Central  Highlands 
minority  groups  have  actually  worsened.  Poor  access  to  health  care  and  education,  lack  of  good-quality 
farmland  in  upland  areas,  limited  access  to  markets,  and  lack  of  fluency  in  the  Vietnamese  language  are 
contributing factors. These findings underscore the importance of tailoring the activities under the Program 
to the different needs and constraints of the most marginalized ethnic minority groups.

includes  a  major  education  component.  While  not  all  migrant  workers  bring  their  families  with  them  to  the 
cities, many do. The dropout rate among unregistered migrant secondary education students is four times 
higher than among regular residents in urban centers. 
 
There  is  also  disparity  between  female  and  male  enrollments  at  all  levels,  and  especially  at  the  lower 
secondary level. While education gender disparity has declined in recent years, it persists among all ethnic 
groups and geographic regions. There are generally no differences in the percentage of students attending 
secondary  schools  between  Kinh  and  ethnic  minority  males  (roughly  73%  for  both),  but  there  is  a 
10 percentage  point  difference  in  female  enrollments  by  ethnicity  (71%  for  Kinh  and  61%  for  ethnic 
minorities). This gender gap varies between ethnic groups and geographic region, but several study findings 
and  multiple  consultations  identify  ethnic  minority  females  as  the  most  disadvantaged  group  at  the 
secondary education level. Semi-boarding at school is particularly difficult for girls because of security and 
privacy concerns. Sociocultural factors also play a role in keeping girls out of school: minority girls tend to 
marry early,  especially in  the Hmong culture. Many children drop out of school in  the absence of parental 
encouragement and discipline, and when parents do not see the relevance of education they do not object. 
Opportunity costs become higher as children enter their teens and are needed for agricultural work, or family 
care in the case of girls.
